data.text: How Do You Protect Your Belongings in Busy Areas when Cycle Touring?
How do you protect your belongings in busy areas like trains known for petty theft? I just had my phone stolen on a French train. Taken from one of my feeder bags.
Keep the important stuff in a bar bag that you never let out of your sight, and take it with you everywhere
data.author: Keith Warner

data.text: Keep valuables in you bar bag and remove from bike when away. I always keep my bike in sight when possible, bad luck for phone.
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text: Wrap the whole bike in a tarp with 50 feet of rope. Makes it inconvenient and nontrivial to access, while completely hiding the bike and bags from plain sight. Vision is the first part of the chain of targeting for a thief. Take your really important stuff with you in a bag ( designated handlebar bag for example)
data.author: Steve Shea

data.text: 50 feet of rope when traveling by train ? !!!!!
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: ,100 feet of 550 (7 strand) Paracord takes only a very small amount of space. You will be using that anyways in camp, or at least I would.
data.author: Steve Shea

data.text: Elven rope. It will come in handy.
data.author: Marshall Parsons

data.text: I do have some lockable steel mesh covers for the panniers. Yet to put them to use however (really not required here in Australia). Maybe for our next international tour in Europe or Asia.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: I have been tour cycling on 5 continents over the past 36 years. Still never carried a rope. But I am also only camping in countries where small roadside hotels are off my budget limit.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: yep, as above : phone, passport , cash in bar bag and or / money pouch. emergency cash hidden in bike e.g. inside seat tube. keep a spare credit card separate too.
data.author: James George

data.text: Keep valuables in a small daypack that you carry at all times. Nobody will steal your dirty laundry. And if they do they will feel sorry.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: You left your phone in an open feeder bag?
data.author: Jeff Roe

data.text: I was packing my valuables in my bags to get ready to leave the train, and they took it right in front of me.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Easy on. everyone makes mistakes and takes risks.
data.author: Neil Wilson

data.text: Sorry, little sympathy from me if you left a phone in a feeder bag. That is just enticing theft. Handle bar bags, and most trunk bags, come with a clip on strap so that you can carry them like a normal shoulder bag, so that you can carry your valuables (including documents) with you. A lot of people also keep a mini/lightweight daypack in a pannier, to carry larger valuables and when off the bike. A daypack also double up for other uses on and off the bike.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: tend to agree. My phone stays *always* on my person. And the handlebar bag is carried with me if the bike is out of direct sight. It is my valuables bag, very portable.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: I keep my important items (wallet, phone, passport, etc) in a bum bag which when I'm with the bike lives in the handlebarbag, and when I leave the bike comes with me. I use a cable and a padlock to lock the bike away, and try to leave it unnatended as little as possible!
data.author: Luca Wright

data.text: On your person. But nothing is perfect. Keep your IT stuff in the cloud. IMO Phone. passport, money and beacon on your body at all times :-)
data.author: Neil Wilson

data.text: That's why proper handlebar bags (as opposed to those impractical 'bikepacking' things) have quick release brackets: so your valuables always stay with you, including EVERY time you park your bike - even for a moment.
data.author: Chris Juden

data.text: that also makes it easier for a thief to swipe the whole bag. I know where I'm from they do that when you're stopped at an intersection.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: That is the first time I have heard of that, but it would be easy to prevent by keeping the strap fitted, and then wrap it around the bar once or twice. Perhaps a more extreme measure for a more extreme circumstance. And still more secure than leaving stuff in a feeder bag.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: the ortleib one I have had a lock, so you lock it in place with a key, and you need to unlock it with the key before being able to remove it
data.author: Luca Wright

data.text: yup, that's why I have the Ortlieb one. It's nice to have that option, but honestly, I don't often feel the need to lock it. I don't enjoy touring that much in places where such measures are wanted.
data.author: Chris Juden

data.text: agreed, I only lock it as a precaution, but I always avoid stopping in areas where it's necessary!
data.author: Luca Wright

data.text: I see you're from Slough. Of despond? Not a place I'm in any hurry to re-visit. But if I do, thanks for the tip to lock my bar bag on whilst passing through!
data.author: Chris Juden

data.text: nah, I live in Slough (near Heathrow in England) but I'm from South Africa. The problem is in the major cities. I rode across South Africa and had zero issues, as have others. Then I came to France and had my phone stolen on the train.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I have the most important things in a Fanny bag ... Purse, phone and vaccine passport :)))
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: doesn't it get in your way while cycling?
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I don't wear it while i cycle. I have it in my pannier while i cycle but take it off whenever i leave my bike somewhere.
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: ah! I prefer that to detachable handle bar bag.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: yeah i get that but i can't stand those :))))
